div.p: Automatically Generating a Large, Culture-Specific Blocklist for China
Austin Hounsel, Prateek Mittal, Nick Feamster Princeton University
Test lists are used as input
Manually curated Citizen Lab Block List
Automatically generated Darer 2017, FilteredWeb Sfakianakis 2011, CensMon
Manually curated: CLBL has 8 commits in
Crowdsourced lists limited to what users submit
CLBL has limited # of China-specific websites
Mostly human rights orgs FilteredWeb doesnt parse
Large, up-to-date, publicly available list of censored domains in China
None of these websites are in the largest blocklist Qualitative analysis of China-specific websites Pull-request into CLBL (in progress)
Censorship findings are only as interesting as the sites and services
What do we mean by phrases?
We use n-grams of Chinese words/phrases as search terms
Example: Chinese human rights violation Bigrams: Chinese human, human rights, rights
Trigrams: Chinese human rights, human rights violation
What do we mean by phrases?
However, because Chinese is written without spaces, word boundaries are probabilistic
We use whatever phrases Stanford CoreNLP outputs
Finding #2: Many unpopular websites are blocked
Finding #3: Political phrases are very effective as search terms
Finding #3: Political phrases are very effective as search terms
Finding #3: Political phrases are very effective as search terms
Add support for other languages to find censored websites pertaining to other countries
Measure churn; do additional websites become (un)censored over time?
We built a large, publicly-available, culture-specific list of censored domains in China
It is important to keep testing lists up to date to understand how censorship in a given country changes over time
